ContributingÂ¶

Contributing to TemplateÂ¶

Thank you for your interest in contributing to this project! This guide will help you get started with contributing to our Python template project.

ğŸ“‹ Table of ContentsÂ¶

  • Code of Conduct

  • Getting Started

  • Development Setup

  • Making Contributions

  • Pull Request Process

  • Coding Standards

  • Testing

  • Documentation

  • AI-Assisted Development

ğŸ¤ Code of ConductÂ¶

This project follows a simple code of conduct: be respectful, inclusive, and constructive in all interactions. We welcome contributions from developers of all backgrounds and experience levels.

ğŸš€ Getting StartedÂ¶

PrerequisitesÂ¶

  • Python 3.12 or higher

  • uv package manager

  • Git

  • A GitHub account

Development SetupÂ¶

  1. Fork and clone the repository:

    git clone https://github.com/your-username/template.git
cd template

  2. Install uv (if not already installed):

    curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh

  3. Install dependencies:

    uv sync --all-extras

  4. Install pre-commit hooks:

    uv run pre-commit install

  5. Verify the setup:

    uv run pytest
uv run ruff check .
uv run pyright modules

ğŸ› ï¸ Making ContributionsÂ¶

Types of ContributionsÂ¶

We welcome several types of contributions:

  • ğŸ› Bug fixes: Fix issues or unexpected behavior

  • âœ¨ New features: Add new functionality

  • ğŸ“š Documentation: Improve docs, examples, or guides

  • ğŸ§ª Tests: Add or improve test coverage

  • âš¡ Performance: Optimize existing code

  • ğŸ§¹ Refactoring: Improve code structure without changing functionality

Finding Something to Work OnÂ¶

  1. Check our Issues for open bugs and feature requests

  2. Look for issues labeled good first issue if youâ€™re new to the project

  3. Check our Discussions for ideas

  4. Propose your own improvements

Before You StartÂ¶

  1. Check if an issue already exists for your contribution

  2. If not, create an issue to discuss your proposed changes

  3. Wait for feedback before starting major work

  4. Assign yourself to the issue to avoid duplicate work

ğŸ”„ Pull Request ProcessÂ¶

1. Create a BranchÂ¶

git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name
# or
git checkout -b fix/issue-number-description

2. Make Your ChangesÂ¶

  • Write clean, readable code

  • Follow our coding standards

  • Add tests for new functionality

  • Update documentation as needed

3. Test Your ChangesÂ¶

# Run all tests
uv run pytest

# Run linting and formatting
uv run ruff check .
uv run ruff format .

# Run type checking
uv run pyright modules

# Run pre-commit checks
uv run pre-commit run --all-files

4. Commit Your ChangesÂ¶

git add .
git commit -m "feat: add your feature description"

Commit Message Convention:

  • feat: for new features

  • fix: for bug fixes

  • docs: for documentation changes

  • test: for test additions/modifications

  • refactor: for code refactoring

  • perf: for performance improvements

  • chore: for maintenance tasks

5. Push and Create a Pull RequestÂ¶

git push origin your-branch-name

Then create a pull request on GitHub using our PR template.

ğŸ“ Coding StandardsÂ¶

Python Code StyleÂ¶

We use several tools to maintain code quality:

  • Ruff: For linting and formatting

  • pyright: For fast static type checking

  • pre-commit: For automated quality checks

Key GuidelinesÂ¶

  1. Type Hints: All functions should have proper type hints

    def process_data(data: list[str], count: int = 10) -> dict[str, int]:
    ...

  2. Docstrings: Use Google-style docstrings

    def example_function(param1: str, param2: int) -> bool:
    """Brief description of the function.

    Args:
        param1: Description of param1.
        param2: Description of param2.

    Returns:
        Description of return value.

    Raises:
        ValueError: Description of when this error is raised.
    """

  3. Error Handling: Use specific exception types and meaningful error messages

    if not data:
    raise ValueError("Data cannot be empty")

  4. Variable Names: Use descriptive names

    # Good
user_count = len(users)

# Bad
n = len(users)

ğŸ§ª TestingÂ¶

Writing TestsÂ¶

  • Place tests in the tests/ directory

  • Mirror the source structure: modules/foo.py â†’ tests/test_foo.py

  • Use descriptive test names that describe what is being tested

def test_process_data_with_valid_input():
    """Test that process_data works correctly with valid input."""
    result = process_data(["a", "b", "c"], count=2)
    assert result == {"a": 1, "b": 1}

Test CoverageÂ¶

  • Aim for >90% test coverage

  • Write both unit tests and integration tests

  • Test edge cases and error conditions

Running TestsÂ¶

# Run all tests
uv run pytest

# Run with coverage
uv run pytest --cov=modules

# Run specific test file
uv run pytest tests/test_specific.py

# Run with verbose output
uv run pytest -v

ğŸ“š DocumentationÂ¶

Code DocumentationÂ¶

  • Write clear docstrings for all public functions and classes

  • Include examples in docstrings when helpful

  • Keep inline comments focused on why, not what

Project DocumentationÂ¶

  • Update README.md for user-facing changes

  • Update CLAUDE.md for changes affecting AI development workflows

  • Add examples for new features

ğŸ¤– AI-Assisted DevelopmentÂ¶

This project is optimized for AI-assisted development with Claude Code.

Using Claude CodeÂ¶

  • Reference CLAUDE.md for comprehensive project context

  • Include AI assistance information in PR descriptions

  • Ensure AI-generated code is reviewed and tested

  • Follow the established development patterns and workflows

Best Practices for AI DevelopmentÂ¶

  1. Review AI suggestions: Always review and understand AI-generated code

  2. Test thoroughly: AI-generated code still needs comprehensive testing

  3. Document AI usage: Note when AI assistance was used in your PR

  4. Maintain quality: AI assistance doesnâ€™t replace code quality standards

  5. Use project context: Leverage the CLAUDE.md file for better AI understanding

ğŸ·ï¸ Release ProcessÂ¶

Releases are managed by maintainers:

  1. Version bumps follow Semantic Versioning

  2. Releases are tagged with v*.*.* format

  3. GitHub Actions automatically builds and publishes releases

  4. Changelog is generated from commit messages

â“ Getting HelpÂ¶

  • Questions: Use GitHub Discussions

  • Bugs: Create an Issue

  • Chat: Join our community discussions

ğŸ™ RecognitionÂ¶

Contributors are recognized in:

  • README.md contributors section

  • Release notes for significant contributions

  • Project documentation where appropriate

Thank you for contributing to our project! Every contribution, no matter how small, helps make this project better for everyone. ğŸ‰
